children.name: shoot b1
children.definition: shoot/ʃuːt/  to point a gun towards sb or sth, and make bullets come out of it in order to kill or injure them :
examples: if you move, i’ll shoot.
make sure you hold the gun steady and shoot straight.
shoot at
armed robbers who shot at a security guard are still being hunted by police.
we used to shoot at empty bottles for practice.
shoot to kill(in order to kill someone)
the defence minister had ordered troops to shoot to kill if attacked.

children.name: fire b2
children.definition: fire/faɪəʳ/  to make bullets come out of a gun, or send an explosive object towards someone or something:
examples: he regained his balance, took aim, and fired.
fire into
the police fired into the air to make the crowd break up.
fire at
as soon as we crossed the border, enemy troops started firing at us.
fire a shot/bullet/round
kendrick fired three shots at the president’s car.
fire a gun/weapon/pistol etc
suddenly the car stopped, and the passenger got out and fired a kalashnikov rifle at the police car.

children.name: open fire c2
children.definition: open fire/ˌəʊpən ˈfaɪəʳ/  to start shooting:
examples: the colonel gave the order for the soldiers to open fire.
open fire on
troops opened fire on a group of unarmed demonstrators in the city centre.

children.name: take a shot at b2
children.definition: take a shot at/ˌteɪk ə ˈʃɒt ætǁ-ˈʃɑːt-/  to shoot once at someone or something, hoping to hit them:
examples: agent cooper stood back and took a shot at the lock on the door.
the police claim that someone took a shot at them, and they had to withdraw for their own safety.

children.name: take a potshot at x
children.definition: take a potshot at to shoot at someone or something, especially from far away, without aiming carefully:
examples: a bird flew out of the tree and harry took a potshot at it.
somebody was taking potshots at us from behind the bushes.

children.name: shot b2
children.definition: shot/ʃɒtǁʃɑːt/  an attempt toshoot someone or something:
examples: his first shot missed. the second hit its target.
fire a shot
police fired shots into the air and used water cannon to disperse the crowd.

children.name: gunfire x
children.definition: gunfire/ˈgʌnfaɪəʳ/  the repeated shooting of a gun or guns:
examples: at least 4 people were killed by gunfire when police stormed the building.
a volley/hail of gunfire
joseph sprinted away to dodge the volley of gunfire.
an exchange of gunfire(when people shoot at each other)
a soldier was killed during an exchange of gunfire at the border station.

children.name: fire c2
children.definition: fire/faɪəʳ/  the repeated shooting of a gun, guns, or other weapons:
examples: ▪ the ship was hit by fire from a german plane.
▪ there was a sudden burst of machine gun fire.
enemy fire
▪ we noticed that the enemy fire was now being directed at our part of the field.

children.name: volley x
children.definition: volley/ˈvɒliǁˈvɑːli/  several shots fired together from several weapons at the same time:
examples: ▪ before it was lowered into the ground, a volley of shots was fired over the general’s coffin.
fire a volley
▪ the soldiers fired a volley into the air as a warning to the crowd.

children.name: bombardment x
children.definition: .bombardment/bɒmˈbɑːʳdməntǁbɑːm-/  the continuous firing of a lot of large guns in order to attack an enemy town, city etc in a war:
examples: ▪ the germans began their bombardment of paris in early 1870.
▪ the devastating air bombardment of the last four weeks is only the latest of a series of assaults by foreign armies.

children.name: barrage x
children.definition: barrage/ˈbærɑːʒǁbəˈrɑːʒ/  the continuous firing of a lot of guns, especially in a war:
examples: ▪ us warplanes continued their barrage again this morning.
▪ a barrage of machine-gun fire

children.name: shelling x
children.definition: shelling/ˈʃelɪŋ/  the shooting at enemy soldiers, cities etc in a war, using large guns that can shoot from long distances : nã pháo
examples: ▪ soon after dawn there was another round of heavy shelling in the eastern part of the city.

children.name: hail of bullets x
children.definition: hail of bullets a lot of bullets that have been fired - used especially in written descriptions: cơn mưa đạn
examples: wallace died in a hail of bullets in los angeles, the victim of a drive-by killing.

children.name: shoot b1
children.definition: shoot/ʃuːt/  to kill or injure someone by firing bullets from a gun:
examples: ▪ i was afraid they were going to shoot us.
▪ rico had been shot by a member of a rival gang.
shoot sb in the back/chest/leg etc
▪ he had been shot in the chest but managed to crawl to safety.
shoot sb dead
▪ a tourist was shot dead by muggers in new orleans last night.

children.name: shoot down x
children.definition: shoot sth down to shoot an aircraft so that it falls from the sky:
examples: local militiamen shot down a federal army helicopter as it flew over the capital.
they said the plane had been on a spy mission and they were justified in shooting it down.

children.name: be hit x
children.definition: be hit /biː ˈhɪt/  to be injured or damaged by bullets:
examples: i didn’t realize he’d been hit until he fell to the ground.
one of our planes has been hit.
be hit in the chest/face etc
he was hit in the arm by a sniper’s bullet but carried on fighting.

children.name: gun down x
children.definition: gun sb down to shoot someone, especially someone who cannot defend themselves, so that they are killed or badly injured:
examples: the bank robbers gunned down two employees who tried to stop them getting away.
two men dragged him out of his home, and gunned him down in the street

children.name: pick off x
children.definition: pick sb off to shoot people or animals one by one from a distance:
examples: jesse hid behind a rock and picked off the sheriff’s men one by one as they rode past.
our rifles were much more powerful and we were able to pick the enemy off before they could even fire at us.

children.name: bring down x
children.definition: bring down to deliberately shoot at or damage a plane while it is flying so that it falls to the ground and crashes: bắn rơi, bắn hạ
examples: one helicopter gunship had been brought down by small-arms fire.
a bomber had been brought down by anti-aircraft fire.

children.name: shot/gunshot x
children.definition: shot/gunshot/ʃɒtǁʃɑːt, ˈgʌnʃɒtǁ-ʃɑːt/  the noise made by a gun when it is fired:
examples: one witness claimed she had heard eight shots.
an occasional gunshot can still be heard, but no-one knows who fires them.
a shot rings out[written]
▪ shots rang out from across the street as someone tried to break up the fight.

children.name: gunfire x
children.definition: gunfire/ˈgʌnfaɪəʳ/  the sound made by several guns being fired, especially in a war:
examples: enemy gunfire could be heard from several kilometres away.
the earth shook with the sound of heavy gunfire.

children.name: to be shot at by sb
be shot at b1
children.definition: be shot at/biː ˈʃɒt ætǁ-ˈʃɑːt-/
examples: i heard a bullet whistle past my ear, and i realized we were being shot at.
the un troops shouldn’t be there just to be shot at -- they should be allowed to defend themselves.

children.name: under fire c2
children.definition: under fire /ʌndəʳ ˈfaɪəʳ/  if someone is under fire, they are being shot at, especially by several people during a battle:
examples: the men’s faces were white with fear -- none of them had ever been under fire before.
under heavy fire
although they were under heavy fire from all sides, they managed to get the wounded off the battlefield.
come under fire(start being shot at)
troops sent to quell the fighting came under fire themselves.

children.name: be caught in the crossfire x
children.definition: be caught in the crossfire if sb is caught in the crossfire, they are trapped between two groups of people who are shooting at each other, and may be shot accidentally themselves:
examples: two civilians were killed when they were caught in the crossfire between the police and the protestors.

children.name: sniper x
children.definition: sniper/ˈsnaɪpəʳ/  someone who hides, especially in a high place, and shoots at enemy soldiers:
examples: weapons were found at three locations believed to be used by snipers.
a sniper’s bullet pierced his windshield and hit him in the eye.

children.name: marksman x
children.definition: marksman/ˈmɑːʳksmən/  someone who is very well trained and very skilful at using a gun, either for sport or for their job with the army or the police:
examples: police marksmen surrounded the building.
a marksman was called in to try and hit the enemy’s machine gun post.

children.name: be a good shot x
children.definition: be a good/bad etc shot/biː ə ˌgʊd ˈʃɒtǁ-ˈʃɑːt/  someone who is a good or bad shot is good or bad at shooting:
examples: you’d have to be a really good shot to get that bird from here.
i used to be the best shot in the whole school.

children.name: to point a gun or weapon carefully before shooting
aim x
children.definition: aim/eɪm/  to choose the place, person etc that you want to hit and point your gun or weapon at it carefully:
examples: ▪ he picked up his shotgun, aimed, then fired.
▪ the firing squad were already aiming their rifles and waiting for the order to shoot.
aim at
▪ which part of the target were you aiming at?
aim for sb’s head/chest etc
▪ you can tell he was a professional killer -- they always aim for the chest.
aim sth at sth
the rocket-launchers are aimed at washington.

children.name: take aim x
children.definition: take aim/ˌteɪk ˈeɪm/   to point a gun or weapon towards sb or sth when preparing to shoot them:
examples: for those few seconds when they are taking aim, the soldiers are exposed to enemy fire.
